awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation: Does Speaking Improve Comprehension and Processing of a Foreign Language? A Computer-Assisted Language Learning and ERP Study
awd_abstract_narration:
Adult language learners, including college students, find learning new languages to be difficult, yet many are remarkably successful. While previous work has focused on cognitive abilities (e.g. fluid intelligence, phonological short-term memory, declarative memory) as indicators of language learning aptitude, less attention has been given to how specific learning tasks might promote language learning in adults. Using a computer-assisted language learning (CALL) protocol, this project introduces an unfamiliar language to college students while varying learning tasks across participant groups. After listening to question-answer dialogues in the novel language, learners are prompted either to generate answers to the questions (i.e. brief phrases in the language), repeat answers to the questions, or answer forced-choice comprehension questions. The impacts on the learning outcomes of the different tasks are measured and assessed. Sessions are conducted remotely and recorded using web-based tools. 

Based on work in cognitive psychology demonstrating benefits of retrieval practice for learning, this project hypothesizes that adults who generate answers will outperform the other groups on tests assessing their comprehension of specific grammatical features of the new language, after controlling for individual differences in aptitude. Researchers hypothesize that after only two CALL sessions, adult learners will show neural markers associated with processing the grammatical structures (i.e. event-related potentials time-locked to errors) that will correlate with comprehension accuracy. Identification of the benefits of retrieval practice for comprehension will inform language learning instruction and aid in the development of effective web and mobile applications. The research will be conducted at a large urban public university with women and members of underrepresented groups involved as key personnel and participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How adults go about practicing a new language plays a role in their success in learning it.  Research in educational and cognitive psychology indicates that practice tests are important in strengthening memory. Our project examined how the format of practice tests, i.e., whether they require matching words to pictures or retrieving and saying the words from memory, influences language learning outcomes. Other research suggests that speaking aloud facilitates language learning. Hence, we also explored whether learners benefit equally from listening and repeating words from the new language (i.e., with no testing component) as compared to attempting to retrieve them from memory and then producing them aloud (i.e., a recall-based practice test).

In computer-assisted language learning sessions conducted on Zoom, adults learned a miniature version of Turkish as a new language. We introduced a vocabulary of Turkish nouns inflected for number (singular, plural) and case (dative [towards], ablative [away from]) in spoken question-answer dialogues. Specific learning tasks, requiring participants to speak aloud and/or complete practice tests, varied across groups. Speaking tasks involved listening and repeating Turkish words or recalling the words from memory and producing them aloud. Practice tests required recognition (select the corresponding picture) or recall (produce the Turkish word). After one hour of exposure to the Turkish dialogues and varied learning tasks, participants were tested on their comprehension of the Turkish vocabulary and grammatical patterns and asked to report what they had noticed about the language. 

Adults were more successful in learning Turkish vocabulary when the tasks required them to speak aloud, as compared to a learning condition where they never produced the words aloud (i.e., recognition-based tests). Moreover, their accuracy in repeating the inflected nouns on the first attempt predicted their vocabulary comprehension at the end of the session, as well as their grasp of Turkish case and number marking. Adults were more successful in learning the Turkish grammatical patterns after completing recognition- or recall-based practice tests. They were also better at learning case marking than plural marking, indicating the increased salience of grammatical markers at the ends of words. Individual differences in learning outcomes were associated with nonverbal ability, but not with language background or bilingualism. 

We also examined whether adult learners develop explicit awareness of what they are learning or whether it is possible for learners to develop good comprehension skills without being able to describe what they have learned. Most participants developed some explicit awareness of Turkish grammatical patterns as their comprehension skills improved. However, some learners demonstrated accurate comprehension without expressing any awareness of the grammar.  As pedagogical recommendations, we suggest that instructors should encourage language learners to speak aloud to strengthen word representations. Both recognition- and recall-based tests are effective in supporting learning of grammatical patterns and may promote meta-lingustic awareness.

In a follow up study using a picture-word verification task, we examined EEG correlates of error detection in adult learners and fluent speakers of Turkish. Prior to the EEG session, the learners completed two computer-assisted language learning sessions where they heard the Turkish nouns in spoken dialogues with recall or recognition-based practice tests. In the EEG session, nouns appeared in syntactic contexts (inflected for dative or ablative case) or in citation (nominative) forms. Both groups showed an increased negativity to semantic errors (N400) with an extended time course; however, the N400 was smaller in magnitude in learners compared to fluent speakers. Further analyses will examine ERPs in response to case and number errors as indicators of grammatical sensitivity. Our preliminary analyses suggest that neural markers of vocabulary comprehension are robust, even at earliest stages of language learning, whereas markers of grammatical processing are more difficult to detect in adult learners.
